metadata.title: Osteoarthritis/Osteoarthrosis  Carpometacarpal Joint of Thumb
anatomical location body part affected: Carpometacarpal (CMC) joint of the thumb, surrounding ligaments, thenar intrinsic musculature
description: Degeneration of the cartilage of the joint (between the first metacarpal and trapezius) at the base of the thumb(10)
The thumb CMC joint is the most common site of hand OA, thought to be associated with high forces on the joint during daily activity involving pinching and gripping(17)
Patients may report pain, weakness, and decreased function. Joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subluxation may be observed on X-ray(26)
Prevalence of symptomatic thumb CMC OA is reported to be up to 15% in persons over age 30 and up to 33% in postmenopausal women(17)

ICD-10 codes.M18.0: bilateral primary osteoarthritis of first carpometacarpal joints
ICD-10 codes.M18.1: unilateral primary osteoarthritis of first carpometacarpal joint
ICD-10 codes.M18.2: bilateral post-traumatic osteoarthritis of first carpometacarpal joints
ICD-10 codes.M18.3: unilateral post-traumatic osteoarthritis of first carpometacarpal joint
ICD-10 codes.M18.4: other bilateral secondary osteoarthritis of first carpometacarpal joints
ICD-10 codes.M18.5: other unilateral secondary osteoarthritis of first carpometacarpal joint
ICD-10 codes.M18.9: osteoarthritis of first carpometacarpal joint, unspecified (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Patients often report pain with specific activities, such as writing, pulling up a zipper, fastening a snap or buttons, twisting a doorknob, turning a key, grasping, pinching, and performing other activities requiring use of the thumb
The pain is usually located at the base of the thumb, often with radiation to the thenar eminence. The pain may progress to constant pain at unacceptable levels that interferes with function(10)
Decreasing lateral (key) pinch strength may be seen early in the course of the development of OA, before extensive radiographic changes are seen(19)

Patients often present with functional impairments related to pain, weakness, and an inability to abduct the thumb.(10) Inability to abduct the thumb makes grasping larger objects difficult. Compensatory hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint of the thumb may occur as CMC ROM decreases

Advanced arthritis of the CMC joint may result in swan-neck  deformity of the thumb, including loss of the first web space, adduction of the metacarpal, MCP joint hyperextension, and CMC dorsal subluxation(17)

Patients may present for rehabilitation following surgical intervention. Therapy will address scar management, ROM, edema, strength, and functional hand use/ADLs/IADLs. The specific interventions will vary based on surgical procedure and patient presentation Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Individuals with generalized ligamentous laxity and a shallow trapezium saddle, especially postmenopausal women, oftendevelop OA due to poor mechanics, instability, and incongruence at the CMC joint(10)
Trauma and intraarticular fractures of the first metacarpal can also precipitate the onset of CMC joint OA(10)
pathogenesis: Gradual degeneration of the articular surfaces of the CMC joint occurs with progressive joint instability. As the diseaseprogresses, loss of strength and ROM occurs, with the development of joint deformities in the later stages(2)–Stage I: Normal articular surface with no degenerative changes; joint may be widened due to effusion or ligament laxity;minimal subluxation–Stage II: Early degenerative changes; mild joint space narrowing; osteophytes less than 2 mm in size may be present; atleast 1/3 joint subluxation–Stage III: More advanced degenerative changes; significant joint space narrowing; osteophytes greater than 2 mm in size;more than 1/3 joint subluxation–Stage IV: Similar to stage III, with addition of scaphotrapezial joint articular changes

Alterations in articular cartilage occur with normal aging(3)–The articular surface becomes thinner–There is reduced matrix tensile strength and stiffness–OA also impacts the integrity of the subchondral bone
The etiology of OA is multifactorial, with mechanical, structural, genetic, and environmental factors that may contribute toits development(4)
Central sensitization might play a role in OA pain(27)–Pain intensity in OA does not always correlate with the extent of joint damage, suggesting that there might be a centralcomponent
risk factors: The risk of CMC joint OA increases with aging and is increased in postmenopausal women, individuals with a historyof trauma or injury to the hand, individuals with rheumatoid arthritis, and individuals who perform repetitive grasping orpinching activities for long periods

It has been estimated that 40 to 60% of cases of OA can be attributed to genetic factors, and in the hand the figure isestimated to be closer to 60%(5)–Research is ongoing to identify the genes and genetic pathways that contribute to the development of OA

overall contraindications precautions: Patients with CMC joint OA should avoid repetitive grasping or pinching activities and should utilize activity modification techniques to minimize progression of OA. Exacerbating activities should be avoided
Refer to physician in presence of systemic findings suggestive of other type of arthritis or findings consistent with scaphoid fracture
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Patients typically present with progressively worsening pain and functional limitation. In some cases, patients present after a traumatic event that results in the onset or exacerbation of symptoms.  Did the patient have a traumatic event? Does patient have occupation or hobby that would put stress on the first CMC joint?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Nonoperative treatment may consist of medications for pain relief/inflammation Strong recommendations for interventions include orthosis fabrication and self-management (e.g., activity modification and joint protection); conditional recommendations include thermal interventions (e.g., local heat or cold)(18) The 2019 American College of Rheumatology/Arthritis Foundation guidelines conditionally recommend intra-articular injections of corticosteroid and conditionally recommend against hyaluronic acid injection(18) Use of stem cell therapy to rejuvenate the articular cartilage is being studied(3) Open or arthroscopic surgery (e.g., abduction-extension  osteotomy, trapeziectomy,debridement, limited resection interposition [LRTI] arthroplasty, arthrodesis, joint replacement surgery) if nonoperative treatment fails
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effectively controlling patient’s symptoms? NSAIDs, including COX-2  inhibitors, to relieve pain and inflammation(10) Chondroitin sulfate and glucosamine sulfate to relieve symptoms(24) Topical treatments (e.g., capsaicin, diclofenac)(10)
diagnostic tests completed: The diagnosis is usually based on clinical examination and X-ray
Blood tests may be performed to rule out rheumatoid arthritis
X-rays  may be used to diagnose and stage CMC joint OA(17)
MRI may be used to evaluate ligament ruptures and dorsal subluxation of the metacarpal.(2) Advanced imaging is rarely indicated(10)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help Topical products used for treatment of OA may include rubefacients (e.g., capsaicin, camphor, methyl salicylate, menthol), arnica, comfrey extract gel, diclofenac and ketoprofen, and herbal medicines The authors of a review of Cochrane reviews found that there is evidence that topical diclofenac and ketoprofen have some (limited) efficacy in hand osteoarthritis(14)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: What are the exacerbating and relieving factors? Aggravating factors may include activities such as writing, turning doorknobs, turning keys, opening jars, and holding heavy objects or prolonged holding (e.g., a book)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much )
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also, document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to the condition
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician. Absence of systemic findings differentiates OA from other types of arthritis. Systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, malaise, low-grade  fever) or inflammation of multiple joints warrants referral to a physician
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any known respiratory compromise? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient also have rheumatoid arthritis? Does the patient have OA in other joints? Has the patient sustained any trauma or undergone surgeries to the involved hand?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, and neurological disorders. Is the patient postmenopausal?
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs or supplements)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: In what types of occupational, leisure, and sports activities does the patient participate? Is the patient able to meet familial responsibilities?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Is the dominant hand affected? What functional deficits is the patient experiencing? -Approximately 80% of individuals with hand OA have limitations in motion and one quarter have limitations in performing ADLs(6) -Is the patient using any adaptive equipment (e.g., non-slip  matting, jar openers, built-up handles)?Inquire about layout of the home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Complete a general exam as indicated with a focus on the items listed below
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient currently use any assistive or adaptive devices? If so, are they appropriate? Devices used may include large-diameter  pens and pencils, large-grip  kitchen tools (e.g., vegetable peeler), and joint protective orthosesThere may be visible enlargement of the joint due to swelling; joint prominence may be related to subluxation. Assess for edema in the CMC joint region as well as the thenar eminence. Compare to the contralateral side. Circumferential or volumetric measurements can be usedAssess as indicatedThe wrist and remaining fingers should be screened to rule out coexisting pathologies (e.g., De Quervain’s tenosynovitis, carpal tunnel syndrome)Assess coordination and ability to manipulate objects; for example –9-hole  peg test –Jebsen-Taylor  Hand Function Test
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess pinch strength (e.g., lateral pinch, 2-point  pinch, tip and tripod) using a pinch gauge. Assess grip strength using a hand dynamometer. Compare to the contralateral side
observation inspection palpation includi: Localized pain and tenderness at the CMC joint are almost always present. Evaluation of the wrist should also be performed to identify other coexisting conditions, such as De Quervain’s tenosynovitis (extensor pollicis brevis [EPB] and abductor pollicislongus [APL] tendon inflammation). Also, identify any deformities of the CMC joint, including subluxation, contracture of the first web space, and compensatory hyperextension of the MCP joint(#)

Inspect for thenar atrophy, trophic changes, swelling, and increased prominence of the CMC joint (which may indicate joint subluxation) •Pain:  Assess for pain at rest, with ROM, and with functional activity using a V AS. Identify exacerbating and relieving

cryotherapy precautions: Hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Cold may be counterproductive if being used to facilitate muscle relaxation and reduce pain in patients who do not tolerate the modality
Contraindicated with open wounds and infected skin lesions
Precautions should be taken with contagious skin conditions to prevent contamination of wax bath
over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
in an area with infection or bleeding
if a tumor is present in the area
in the area of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis
other: Relevant therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications include; do not use:(8)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: CMC joint OA, which may include some or all of the following symptoms ROM and strength, impaired function, and physical deformity
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Rheumatoid arthritis De Quervain’s tenosynovitis Carpal tunnel syndrome Fracture (e.g., scaphoid, base of the first metacarpal) Torn ulnar collateral ligament (e.g., gamekeeper’s thumb) Flexor or extensor tendon injury (e.g., avulsion of the extensor tendon)
prognosis: OA is a progressive disease of a joint in which there is failed repair of joint damage due to intraarticular stresses. Prognosis is variable depending on the extent of the disease(9)
Treatment can be effective in slowing the progression and alleviating symptoms, but ongoing deterioration of the joint should be expected
There is often inconsistency between radiographic findings and the clinical presentation (i.e., patient’s perception of severity)(#)

Progression of OA in the hand includes changes in biomechanics, but the role of the changes to the oblique or “beak” ligament is unclear. In basal joint OA, degeneration can be seen at the trapeziometacarpal joint and can progress to pantrapezial arthritis with a deformity pattern of thumb adduction and MCP hyperextension(10)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Occupational therapy for adaptive equipment, such as built-up  handles for writing/eating, devices for opening jars, ergonomic assessment, etc., and ADL training Occupational therapy/hand therapy for splint/orthosis fabrication or fitting Physician for worsening symptoms or lack of progress, or if conservative measures are failing to alleviate symptoms and more-invasive  treatment may be required Dietician for weight reduction, if indicated
other considerations: Surgical intervention (e.g., joint arthroplasty) may be indicated in advanced disease or when conservative measures are not successful –The authors of a prospective cohort study found that patients who experienced pain reduction with nonoperative treatment were less likely to have surgery(24)

Patient expectations for improvements with treatment may influence treatment outcome(22) –The authors of a case control study of patients treated at a single institution in the United States found that pain relief, improved hand strength, improved ability to use the hand for functional activities (e.g., write, use cell phone, tie a knot, open a jar, use a knife), and preventing the hand condition from getting worse were common expectations for treatment
treatment summary: Pain management, rest, and CMC joint immobilization (orthosis/splinting) are the mainstays of conservative management of CMC joint OA. Strengthening and stretching are also incorporated into therapy, taking precautions to avoid exacerbation of symptoms. NSAIDs, analgesics, corticosteroid injections, and other medications can be useful in the general management of pain and symptoms. Surgical treatment is indicated for cases in which nonoperative treatment is ineffective and pain is unacceptable(10,24) –Neurodynamic techniques -Radial nerve mobilization might decrease pain and increase tip pinch strength in patients with CMC OA(13) –Multimodal intervention -A combination of manual therapy and exercise may be beneficial to decrease pain in CMC OA(15) -Based on an RCT conducted in Italy  -Sixty patients were randomly assigned to receive intervention that included joint mobilization, neural mobilization, and exercise or a sham intervention -There was a greater decrease in pain intensity in the intervention group than in the placebo group. No changes in pinch or grip strength were obtained –OA group intervention(16) -The authors of a study designed to assess the efficacy of a 2-month  group intervention found that function (grip strength, resting pain, functional UE use), activity engagement, and self-reported  health status improved at the end of the intervention, and the improvements were still seen at 1-year  post intervention follow-up -The group intervention included: -patient education (joint changes with OA, risk factors, ADLs, management strategies) -exercise session (2x/week for 6 weeks) consisting of paraffin wax x 20 minutes followed by upper extremity ROM and strengthening exercise with progression to strengthening as tolerated by the individual patient –Splints/orthoses -Custom-made  and prefabricated orthoses are available that are designed to reduce pain and improve strength and functional hand use -. Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Pain, tenderness, inflammation, and edemaResolve/reduce pain, inflammation, and edemaSplinting _ An orthosis/splint that immobilizes the CMC joint can be helpful in reducing or eliminating pain, but the specific orthosis design that is most beneficial has not been defined.(11) A short opponens orthosis or CMC orthosis that achieves CMC joint immobilization is effective in allowing functional use of the hand while resting the CMC joint. Custom fabricated and prefabricated orthoses (e.g., Push thumb orthosis, neoprene thumb supports) are available and made from a variety of materials (e.g.,low-temperature thermoplastic, neoprene, bendable wire encased in tubing, fabrifoam). When providing anorthosis, leaving the wrist, MP and IP joints free can allow for increased hand function _ _

maintenance or prevention: Patients with CMC joint OA should continue to employ rest, activity modification, orthosis use, ROM, and strengthening, as indicated, to alleviate symptoms and help delay/minimize the progression of joint degeneration
Use of joint protection techniques positively affects the course of the disease(12)
Self-management  education contributes to improved QOL(12)
